push_data.commit_title: Use modern GObject decl macro for GtkOsxApplication

note.body:
@jralls 

> use [`G_OBJECT_DEFINE_TYPE_WITH_PRIVATE`](https://docs.gtk.org/gobject/func.DEFINE_TYPE_WITH_PRIVATE.html) instead of `G_OBJECT_DEFINE_TYPE_WITH_CODE`.

Is done.

> As long as you're modernizing you should also replace the `GTKOSX_APPLICATION*` defines in gtkosxapplication.h with [`G_DECLARE_FINAL_TYPE`](https://docs.gtk.org/gobject/func.DECLARE_FINAL_TYPE.html) and delete the typedef for `GtkosxApplicationClass`.

Couldn't figure it out how to.

@jralls 

Just adapted the deprecated G_TYPE_INSTANCE_GET_PRIVATE
 - Does build fine
 - Runtime check with Bluefish 2.2.16 (build with macports) ok
 - Adapted glib version check to minimum glib version 2.38.00

For the time I just commented the old code\
I added one extra debug line to see if GtkOsxApplication is really used.\
If extra testing and checks by other are ok I will remove those and issue a new clean pull request.

note.body:
@jralls 

Now I start with the last deprecated function use. This one is since version glib >= 2.58
It is there for quit a while but I'm afk it will not remain usable for long when glib is updated.
in macports we still us 2.78 but homebrew is already at version 2.8.*

```
gtkosxapplication_quartz.c:599:16: warning: Deprecated pre-processor symbol: replace with "G_ADD_PRIVATE" [-W#pragma-messages]
  self->priv = GTKOSX_APPLICATION_GET_PRIVATE (self);
               ^
./gtkosxapplicationprivate.h:32:47: note: expanded from macro 'GTKOSX_APPLICATION_GET_PRIVATE'
#define  GTKOSX_APPLICATION_GET_PRIVATE(obj)    (G_TYPE_INSTANCE_GET_PRIVATE ((obj), GTKOSX_TYPE_APPLICATION, GtkosxApplicationPrivate))
                                                 ^
/opt/local/include/glib-2.0/gobject/gtype.h:686:145: note: expanded from macro 'G_TYPE_INSTANCE_GET_PRIVATE'
#define G_TYPE_INSTANCE_GET_PRIVATE(instance, g_type, c_type)   ((c_type*) g_type_instance_get_private ((GTypeInstance*) (instance), (g_type))) GOBJECT_DEPRECATED_MACRO_IN_2_58_FOR(G_ADD_PRIVATE)
                                                                                                                                                ^
/opt/local/include/glib-2.0/gobject/gobject-visibility.h:584:49: note: expanded from macro 'GOBJECT_DEPRECATED_MACRO_IN_2_58_FOR'
#define GOBJECT_DEPRECATED_MACRO_IN_2_58_FOR(f) GLIB_DEPRECATED_MACRO_FOR (f)
```

Think to have to solution but that one will have to be tested extra at runtime.

@jralls 

What could be improved is move the defines\
```
#if MAC_OS_X_VERSION_MIN_REQUIRED < 101200

#define GDK_QUARTZ_COMMAND_KEY_MASK NSCommandKeyMask
```

note.body: close this merge request will make a new one with adapted changes

@christophecvr 
AvailablityMacros.h does this:
```
 * Note: compiler driver may set _ENVIRONMENT_MAC_OS_X_VERSION_MIN_REQUIRED_ based on MACOSX_DEPLOYMENT_TARGET environment variable
 */
#ifndef MAC_OS_X_VERSION_MIN_REQUIRED
    #ifdef __ENVIRONMENT_MAC_OS_X_VERSION_MIN_REQUIRED__
        #if (__i386__ || __x86_64__) && (__ENVIRONMENT_MAC_OS_X_VERSION_MIN_REQUIRED__ < MAC_OS_X_VERSION_10_4)
            #warning Building for Intel with Mac OS X Deployment Target < 10.4 is invalid.
        #endif
        #define MAC_OS_X_VERSION_MIN_REQUIRED __ENVIRONMENT_MAC_OS_X_VERSION_MIN_REQUIRED__
    #else
        #if __i386__ || __x86_64__
            #define MAC_OS_X_VERSION_MIN_REQUIRED MAC_OS_X_VERSION_10_4
        #elif __arm__ || __arm64__
            #define MAC_OS_X_VERSION_MIN_REQUIRED MAC_OS_X_VERSION_10_5
        #else
            #define MAC_OS_X_VERSION_MIN_REQUIRED MAC_OS_X_VERSION_10_1
        #endif
     #endif
#endif
```
so `#if MAC_OS_X_VERSION_MAX_ALLOWED >= 101400 && !defined(MAC_OS_X_VERSION_MIN_REQUIRED)` is never true. Your code is equivalent to
```
#if MAC_OS_X_VERSION_MIN_REQUIRED < 101000
    imageContext = [[NSGraphicsContext currentContext] graphicsPort];
#else
    imageContext = [[NSGraphicsContext currentContext] CGContext];
```
So this won't crash, but it also doesn't change anything unless you build with VERSION_MIN > 101000. In this particular case that's OK until Apple removes `graphicsPort`. They may never do so, but there are other symbols that they have removed so in general you need both compile time and run time checks to prevent crashes.

The code I fed you up top is how gdk/quartz [does it](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gtk/-/blame/gtk-3-24/gdk/quartz/gdkwindow-quartz.c?ref_type=heads#L165). You'll find plenty of similar examples throughout the Gtk2 and Gtk3 code, we've been doing it this way for a very long time.

> If it is ok

It's not OK and there's no way to make it OK without runtime checks.

@jralls 

The above has been tested and works perfect I can build if requested for lower then macos-101000 which then issue by me a deprecation warning cause it builds with graphicports.
Default build no problem CGContext is used.

If it is ok I can continu with the other deprecations and solve in same way.
Only how to look up if a specific new item is already avbl on macos xx but the old way not deprecated yet ?

@jralls 

oeps small correction on the above is the first line using : 

`#if MAC_OS_X_VERSION_MAX_ALLOWED >= 101400 && !defined(MAC_OS_X_VERSION_MIN_REQUIRED)`

is the right one

Like it is it should now be 100 % bullet proof.
- Building from source on macports or homebrew when for native only the flag :\
  `MAC_OS_X_VERSION_MAX_ALLOWED=<used sdk>`
  will be set.
- Building for else then native will always require extra flags set by user MAC_OS_X_VERSION_MIN_REQUIRED
- Build with Xcode package creator will request the flags anyway.

Sorry to annoy here but if we will move on the used way should be: 
- bullet proof
- No deprecation upstream
- Keep support for older macos much as possible (I find)
- Keep everywhere the same way

@jralls 

> That's not how `MAC_OS_X_VERSION_MAX_ALLOWED` works. If you build with `MAC_OS_X_VERSION_MAX_ALLOWED=150000` (implied by building with the current SDK if you don't set it explicitly in CFLAGS) someone can still use the library on a Mac running 10.9.

Yes i get the point here,but that is when you build for further distribution of build packages. in a .pkg package or full bundle path form. Then of course those extra flags must be set in order to avoid that users running 10.9 can use it with a result of crash and segfaults and so on ...
Then indeed those extra flags will have to be set explicitly to CFLAGS and Info.plist for the Bundle.app . However those flags are not needed when you build from source for local (actually well in certain way) but like the MAC_OS_X_VERSION_MAX_ALLOWED=101400 or 150000 are set by the sdk for the framework sdk self then. Guess if I would set explicitly  in CFLAGS MAC_OS_X_VERSION_MAX_ALLOWED=1OO9OO when building with sdk 10.15
It will use the graphics version cause MAC_OS_X_VERSION_MAX_ALLOWED < 101000 was used. The result will only work for macos < 10.10 and not by my self since I'm using macos 10.15 . 

More relastic:
- Known facts Deprecated is only as from Macos-1014
- CGContext is implemented since Macos-1010
- Today graphics is still working up to Macos-15 yes but in development meant to be implemented upstream always avoid deprecated stuff.\
  but do not break build on older Macos (i find)
- On macos here You always will have to link against a build sdk so if You're building with 10.15 sdk : \
  Flag CFLAGS MAC_OS_X_VERSION_MAX_ALLOWED=10.15 will be set but MAC_OS_X_VERSION_MIN_REQUIRED not. 

Maybe for this item then set rather 

```
#if MAC_OS_X_VERSION_MAX_ALLOWED > 101300 && !defined(MAC_OS_X_VERSION_MIN_REQUIRED)
    imageContext = [[NSGraphicsContext currentContext] CGContext];
#elif defined(MAC_OS_X_VERSION_MIN_REQUIRED) && MAC_OS_X_VERSION_MIN_REQUIRED < 101000
    imageContext = [[NSGraphicsContext currentContext] graphicsPort];
#else
    imageContext = [[NSGraphicsContext currentContext] CGContext];
#endif
``` 
I just tested it out.

I'm building on macos 10.15 with SDK 10.15 . No extra options set.\
Perfect build No deprecated warning about use of graphics which means it builds with CGContext

Building on the macos 10.15 with SDK 10.15 added CFLAG -DMAC_OS_X_VERSION_MIN_REQUIRED=100900 and yes deprecated warning : 

> gtkosx-image.c:104:56: warning: 'graphicsPort' is deprecated: first deprecated in macOS 10.14 [-Wdeprecated-declarations]

It used indeed the line 104 which is just below the #elif.

This should work perfect now with no deprecated stuff and produce always a stable library.

> Do you know a couple off applications which are using this GtkOsxApplication from gtk-mac-integration fully (not just some functions of it )?

Two that I maintain: [GnuCash](https://github.com/gnucash/gnucash) and [Gramps](https://github.com/gramps-project/Gramps).

> Ok the above works by me I did not had to add any extra cflag. but with just simple

Works for you is not good enough. It has to work for everybody. 

> For builds allowing lower then 101400 os_version graphics port will be used and working at run time. no build warnings att all. For builds not allowing lower then 101400 CGContext will be used and work at runtime. no build warnings will show up at all.

That's not how `MAC_OS_X_VERSION_MAX_ALLOWED` works. If you build with `MAC_OS_X_VERSION_MAX_ALLOWED=150000` (implied by building with the current SDK if you don't set it explicitly in CFLAGS) someone can still use the library on a Mac running 10.9.

@jralls 

Do you know a couple off applications which are using this GtkOsxApplication from gtk-mac-integration fully (not just some functions of it )?

Since I did found the solution for the 
```
gtkosxapplication_quartz.c:608:16: warning: Deprecated pre-processor symbol: replace with "G_ADD_PRIVATE" [-W#pragma-messages]
:info:build   self->priv = GTKOSX_APPLICATION_GET_PRIVATE (self);
:info:build                ^
:info:build ./gtkosxapplicationprivate.h:32:47: note: expanded from macro 'GTKOSX_APPLICATION_GET_PRIVATE'
:info:build #define  GTKOSX_APPLICATION_GET_PRIVATE(obj)    (G_TYPE_INSTANCE_GET_PRIVATE ((obj), GTKOSX_TYPE_APPLICATION, GtkosxApplicationPrivate))
```

After my solution it build fine without warnings but I need a application which is also using it fully (gedit does not).

Ok the above works by me I did not had to add any extra cflag. but with just simple

```
#if MAC_OS_X_VERSION_MAX_ALLOWED < 101400
    imageContext = [[NSGraphicsContext currentContext] graphicsPort];
#else

    imageContext = [[NSGraphicsContext currentContext] CGContext];
#endif

```

For builds allowing lower then 101400 os_version
 graphics port will be used and working at run time. no build warnings att all.
For builds not allowing lower then 101400 
 CGContext will be used and work at runtime. no build warnings will show up at all.

And if you cross compile build for say sdk 10.09 100900 then also no warnings will show since it will use graphicsport. also since max allowed is below 101400 . We always needs to link against a framework anyway.

Thanks for taking this up.

>but this change only is applicable since macos 101400 (Mojave).

No, `CGContext` is first defined for [10.10](https://developer.apple.com/documentation/appkit/nsgraphicscontext/1524878-cgcontext?language=objc). `graphicsPort` is deprecated in [10.14](https://developer.apple.com/documentation/appkit/nsgraphicscontext/1524878-cgcontext?language=objc) though it's still in the header in 15, which is why you get deprecation warnings instead of unknown symbol errors.

The problem is that just because you build with MAX_ALLOWED >= 10.14 doesn't mean that you don't have users running 10.9 or earlier--Gtk3 supports 10.4 and later--and retrieving CGContext won't work for them. So to silence the deprecation warning the code would be
```
#if MAC_OS_X_VERSION_MAX_ALLOWED < 101000
    imageContext = [[NSGraphicsContext currentContext] graphicsPort];
#else
# if MAC_OS_X_VERSION_MIN_REQUIRED < 101000
  if (gdk_quartz_osx_version () < GDK_OSX_YOSEMITE)
    imageContext = [[NSGraphicsContext currentContext] graphicsPort];
  else
#endif
    imageContext = [[NSGraphicsContext currentContext] CGContext];
#endif
```
then set MAC_OS_X_VERSION_MIN_REQUIRED to 101000 in CFLAGS and LSMinimumSystemVersion to 10.10 in the app's Info.plist.
